div.p: This scenario examines how the BIM plans evolve over time.
This scenario does not talk about the updates based on the observed data (such as images, point clouds and voxel clouds).
It is about the updates of the federated BIM model.

model.name: bim3d
model.p: This BIM model is provided after the planning phase and updated throughout the construction.
The plan is updated as the building grows.
This is the federated model of all the individual domain models.
We assume that the model excludes the time, schedule, the tasks, the costs, the actors etc.

model.name: bim_extended
model.p: This model extends by including additional entities which were not provided in the official plan.
These additional entities are linked to the entities in .

def.name: guid
def.p: A guid is a globally unique identifier.
It is specified by building smart.

def.name: revision

p.phase: The revision is an official version of a at different stages of construction.

def.p: It happens maybe once a week per an important model.
These changes are official and they have to be signed-off (by a civil engineer, construction engineer etc.) and are legally binding.

def.name: extension_update
def.p: The entities of the are changed internally by our system.
The updates are not officially binding and can happen arbitrary often (e.g., multiple times a day).

def.name: non_ifc_entity
def.p: Non-IFC entity is an entity of our system that can not be modeled as an IFC class.
The non-IFC entities are shadowed in by IfcExternalReference.
Though IfcExternalReference is usually used for documents, we use it here in the sense of REpresentational State Transfer (REST) where everything is considered a "resource".

def.name: explorer
def.p: The explorer allows us to view instances in and in a browser.
This is a very low-level tool (not for visualizing 3D geometry!) and should not allow any modifications to the models as these are gate-kept by the system (and could break it).

def.name: site_coordinate_system
def.p: This is the coordinate system of the building site.
All the elements from live in this coordinate system.
The unit is always a meter.

level.name: site
level.p: The planning of a construction site consist of two models:

ul.li: an official plan (only 3D geometry, officially signed off), and
an internal, extended plan (changed more frequently, covering abstract entities such as tasks, actors, costs, more dynamic zones etc., not officially signed off).

div.p: The official is updated through s. As these revisions are costly and official, they are not frequently done.
The of the internal occurs much more frequently than the official s. For example, when a new is inserted into the system.
Inconsistencies. On every , there might be inconsistency introduced between and .
For example, during planning, we might refer to entities which have not been designed yet.

p.phase: An another example. An entity of is deleted in a because it should not be eventually built, but it is referred to by a task entity in .

div.p: We consciously expect these two models to be actually inconsistent.
The system should provide an application to highlight the inconsistencies.
Globally unique identification. We expect entities in and to have s globally unique with the respect to their union. A in should not conflict with a in , but mean the same entity.
For example, you should not give the same to a wall and to an organization.
In order to make these entities referencable by IFC entities, every needs to be shadowed in as an IfcExternalReference.
Visualization of entities. The system should provide a viewer of the entities.

This viewer is not meant for visualization of 3D geometry, but for exploration of existing entities and their links to non-IFC entities. This viewer is more like a database viewer (kind of a "PhpMyAdmin" for BIM).

We might use a tool such as https://ifcwebserver.org/ (Section "Innovative Graph database data management"). In case we want to support the links to s, we might need to implement an explorer on our own (e.g., using a simple viewer in a browser based on s).
We adapt to in parallel to have a semantically interpretable representation of the physical world.
However, is not considered a "plan", but an "observation".

test.name: inconsistent_model
test.p: We test the system with manually designed and with inconsistencies introduced on purpose.

acceptance.name: inconsistencies_dealt_with_gracefully
acceptance.p: The system needs to deal with the s in a graceful manner. For example, dangling references should be checked and should not raise an exception or break down the system.
